message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest dilated cardiomyopathy, which is characterized by inflammation and damage to the heart muscle. Among the options, infiltration with lymphocytes is the most commonly seen microscopic finding in endomyocardial biopsies of patients with dilated cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute myocarditis, which is commonly caused by viral infections. The most common type of myocarditis is lymphocytic myocarditis, hence infiltration with lymphocytes is the expected microscopic finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest acute heart failure, and the subsequent tests show severe dilation of all heart cavities, ejection fraction of 23%, and mitral regurgitation. EMB is ordered to further investigate the cause. Infiltration with lymphocytes is commonly seen in viral myocarditis, which can be caused by an upper respiratory tract infection. Infiltration with eosinophils is seen in eosinophilic myocarditis, which is rare. Infiltration with neutrophils is seen in acute bacterial or fungal myocarditis, which is also rare. Infiltration with granulomas is seen in sarcoidosis-associated myocarditis, which typically presents with less severe symptoms and a more chronic course.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest heart failure, and the subsequent tests reveal severe dilation of all heart cavities and mitral regurgitation. These are consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy, which is often associated with lymphocytic infiltration in the EMB. Infiltration with eosinophils is more commonly seen in hypereosinophilic syndrome, and infiltration with neutrophils is seen in myocarditis. Infiltration with granulomas is not commonly seen in dilated cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and test results suggest myocarditis. Among the options, infiltration with lymphocytes is the most commonly seen microscopic finding in myocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest the patient has dilated cardiomyopathy, and the most common microscopic finding in dilated cardiomyopathy is infiltration with lymphocytes. Infiltration with eosinophils is more commonly seen in eosinophilic myocarditis, while infiltration with neutrophils is seen in acute myocarditis. Infiltration with granulomas is seen in giant cell myocarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient presentation, the most likely diagnosis is acute myocarditis, which is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the myocardium. Eosinophilic infiltrates are seen in eosinophilic myocarditis, which is a rare subtype. Neutrophilic infiltrates can be seen in bacterial or fungal infections, but this is less likely in this case. Granulomas are seen in sarcoidosis, which is another possible cause of myocarditis, but lymphocytic infiltration is more common.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest myocarditis, which is characterized by infiltration with lymphocytes. Eosinophil infiltration is more commonly seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome, while neutrophil infiltration is associated with bacterial infections. Granulomas are seen in sarcoidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest myocarditis, which is inflammation of the heart muscle. The most common microscopic finding in EMB for myocarditis is infiltration with lymphocytes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of myocarditis, which is an inflammation of the heart muscle. Among the options, infiltration with lymphocytes is the most commonly seen finding in myocarditis on endomyocardial biopsy.
